body:
Pytest always evaluates those eagerly 

So the memory argument is a strawman

Please use lists

issue.title: Add warning about generators for parametrizing class or module

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
I stumbled across this issue when trying to write some tests and took a while to figure out the issue.
Based on #13409, it sounds like this is expected behavior.

This PR adds a warning to https://docs.pytest.org/en/stable/how-to/parametrize.html so that hopefully other people don't waste cycles debugging this behavior.

body:
Some possible solutions: 1. Just document this gotcha, otherwise keep as is (pr #13742) 2. Deprecate and eventually stop accepting non-`Sequence` (or whatever suitable ABC) argvalues, including in the typing 3. Cache the iterator evaluation. I made a very ugly hack below to cache on the mark itself to see if there are any issues (it seems to work, and doesn't break any tests), but needs a cleaner way.
Hacky caching

```diff diff --git a/src/_pytest/python.py b/src/_pytest/python.py index 3f9da0267..133eecc09 100644 --- a/src/_pytest/python.py +++ b/src/_pytest/python.py @@ -111,7 +111,17 @@ def pytest_addoption(parser: Parser) -> None: def pytest_generate_tests(metafunc: Metafunc) -> None: for marker in metafunc.definition.iter_markers(name="parametrize"): - metafunc.parametrize(*marker.args, **marker.kwargs, _param_mark=marker) + if len(marker.args) >= 2: + args = list(marker.args) + if not hasattr(marker, "_argvalues_cache"): + if not isinstance(args[1], Sequence): + args[1] = list(args[1]) + object.__setattr__(marker, "_argvalues_cache", args[1]) + else: + args[1] = marker._argvalues_cache + else: + args = marker.args + metafunc.parametrize(*args, **marker.kwargs, _param_mark=marker) ```

I find 2 tempting, it arguably was a mistake to allow iterators here. Interestingly there is an old issue #122 which discusses this and updated the `parametrize` marker doc to clarify only list and tuple are accepted (which we actually [never updated...](https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/blob/184f5f1dfe3b8c987304b05bbacc2da86d8ad7d3/src/_pytest/python.py#L122-L123)). But probably it would be too much breakage, especially since it would break stuff like `map` and `zip` (but not `range`). Any opinions/other ideas?
WDYT about special-casing the case of "exhausted generator" in the code generating (hah!) the "got empty parameter set" skip, and turning it into a warning instead?

> WDYT about special-casing the case of "exhausted generator" in the code generating (hah!) the "got empty parameter set" skip, and turning it into a warning instead?

I suspect it might not be desirable because there might be cases where the original iterator being empty makes sense. Like if it's generated dynamically or conditionally and sometimes might be legitimately empty.

> lets warn on any iterator

I'm thinking that might be the way. It will be a big annoying deprecation but it's just a footgun. And the caching solution can be misleading.
Yep, I think we should deprecate use of iterables which are not collections.

rename.from: Parameterized tests with generator as data source fail on second pytest.main() call
rename.to: Deprecate iterables which are not collections (e.g. generators) for tests parametrization

body:
So the question is what type we should use.

One way would be `Iterable & ~Iterator`. Iterable because we need to iterate, and not Iterator because that means it would be exhausted on first iteration.

But I'm thinking we can use `Iterable & Sized`. Sized because parametrizations *should* have a finite size (correct me if I'm wrong), so it will reject infinite iterables, and it still rules out all of the bad stuff I can think of.

A simpler ready made alternative would be `collections.abc.Collection` which is `Iterable & Sized & Container`. But I think `Container` (type implements `__contains__`) is unneeded, it will for example reject `itertools.repeat("foo", 5)`.

So my suggestion is:
- Add a `SizedIterable[T]` class which inherits from `Iterable[T]` and `Sized`, then use it in `Metafunc.parametrize` for the `argvalues` and `ids` parameters. This is an immediate deprecation in the typing level; alternatively we can add an overload with `@deprecated`, didn't try it but could be nice if it works.
- At runtime, check isinstance `Iterable` and `Sized` and issue deprecation warning if not.
thanks for exploring the details -  i all in with the suggestion - lets try deprecated overload with it as its nice to have

I think we should indeed use `Collection`; it's a simpler way to specify what we want.

(and for the sake of argument, iterating `itertools.repeat("foo", 5)` only produces elements the first time!)

Right, for some reason I thought it returns an iterable (like `range`) but it returns an iterator directly.

So let's go with `Collection`. I verified that `pydoc iterootls | grep __contains__`  is empty  so nothing in there will be accepted at least.

Regarding `ids`, since 2019 (see #759) caching is already implemented for it, and using iterators (e.g. `ids=itertools.count(1)`) is a documented feature. It is implemented in an ungodly way (added 2 private fields to `class Mark` itself!), but since it is already implemented for a long time, is documented, kinda useful and not a footgun, I suggest we don't deprecate iterators in `ids`. But I wouldn't want to extend the hack to `argvalues`.

issue.title: Deprecate passing iterator argvalues to parametrize

labels.name: bot:chronographer:provided
labels.description: (automation) changelog entry is part of PR

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body: Fixes #13409 by deprecating non-`Collection` argvalues as described in the issue. The deprecation is both in runtime and in type checking time (via the new `@warning.deprecated` decorator, though it's not enabled in mypy by default yet).

body: I think its fine to deprecate that as well
